MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Home Help Scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if in view of the increasing necessity for many married women to go out to work, he will have an investigation carried out as to the need and demand for the provision of (a) home help scheme, (b) nursery schools and (c) crèche schools to assist such women.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lalor) (for the Minister for Health) Patrick J. Lalor
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lalor) (for the Minister for Health)
Speaker.P: While it would be possible in certain cases, under section 61 of the Health Act, 1970, to provide home helps as a health service in the circumstances mentioned in the question, I should say that the service will not come into operation until 1st April, 1971, and that the range which can be provided from that date will necessarily have to be phased to take account of the personnel and finance available to health boards and to the high priority which must be given to care of the aged and of the handicapped living at home.

An inquiry made by my Department late in 1967 indicated that there did not seem to be a demand either for nursery schools or crèches outside the cities of Dublin and Cork. In Dublin I am aware that, apart from a number operated privately, four crèches or day nurseries provided by voluntary organisations or religious bodies with approximately 120 places have been in operation for some time, that a fifth with approximately 20 places was started recently and that a sixth, with approximately 40 places, is in process of being established.

Would the Minister not agree that a survey carried out in 1967 is somewhat out of date now and that the indications are that there is an increasing need for this type of school? Will he undertake to have a new survey carried out to ascertain present needs?
I will convey the Deputy's views to the Minister.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin Health Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will comment on the reported statement of the chief psychiatrist of the Dublin Health Authority on 16th July, 1970, that the authority had totally failed to create a service for geriatric patients and for the adult mentally handicapped, that the authority was facing the problem a decade behind the time and that it will be five times more difficult to get nurses to work in the conditions applying in the future; and what action he proposes to take to remedy the serious deficiencies in accommodation and services.

I have seen press reports of a recent meeting of the Dublin Health Authority which attributed to the chief psychiatrist of that authority the statements referred to by the Deputy. So far as these statements may be taken as being critical of the work of the Dublin Health Authority it is, of course, primarily a matter for that authority, rather than the Minister for Health to deal with it.

As a general comment, I think it is true to say that no country, including those far wealthier than we are, would claim that they have reached a stage where they are fully satisfied with the services that they provide for geriatrics and for the adult mentally handicapped. The chief psychiatrist referred in the quotation to deficiencies in services. The Deputy, I note, puts accommodation before services. There are undoubtedly defects in the quality of some of the accommodation available under public authority and voluntary agencies in Dublin but the problem in the case of geriatrics is more one of developing community supportive services rather than merely adding to the number of institutional beds. Indeed, the statistics available to me make it clear that institutional places in Dublin are on a level considerably in excess of the provision in other parts of the country and approaching double the target indications proposed in the Report on the Care of the Aged.

On the general question of the improvement of the geriatric services, the Report on the Care of the Aged is being actively considered both in my Department and by the various authorities concerned. The programme which I hope to see put into action in this area of growing importance in our health and welfare services, is one to which I attach great importance and I shall be announcing the action to be taken as soon as possible.

MainHeading.P: In the case of the mentally handicapped, the Dublin Health Authority in common with all health authorities in the country avail of the institutional services provided by voluntary bodies. The Commission of Inquiry on Mental Handicap examined all aspects of the services for the mentally handicapped and recommended that there should be 2,500 places for adults centred at the special residential institutions under the control of these voluntary bodies. Over 1,750 of these places have already been provided and when the schemes at present in progress or in planning are completed the commission's targets for residential accommodation for the adult mentally handicapped at the special centres will be met. In the Dublin area 180 additional places are being provided for adults at these centres.

The Commission of Inquiry saw no objection in principle to the provision of long-term care for the adult mentally handicapped in conjunction with the long-term care of the mentally ill at district mental hospitals provided it would be possible to make available suitable and separate living accommodation for the mentally handicapped. At present, there is a scheme in planning for St. Ita's, Portrane, which is aimed at providing this type of separate accommodation for the adult mentally handicapped. The Dublin Health Authority are examining as a matter of urgency the possibility of the immediate transfer from St. Ita's of geriatric patients who do not require the services of a mental hospital so as to provide alternative accommodation for mentally handicapped patients at present housed in unsatisfactory wards.

I am satisfied that with the participation of voluntary bodies and health authorities in the services and the extension and improvement of facilities, including the provision of trained staff, a satisfactory service will be provided for the adult mentally handicapped in the Dublin area and in the country generally.

Speaker.P: In thanking the Minister for his detailed reply may I put it to him that the very trenchant criticism by the chief psychiatrist, Dr. Ivor Browne, contained a great deal of objective analysis of the very significant deficiencies of the psychiatric, geriatric and mental handicap services in the Dublin area and therefore would the Minister make a very special attempt to keep these services, their reform and development under very urgent review having regard to the increase in the number of elderly persons in the population of Dublin and the substantial services currently being developed in the country?

As the Deputy will appreciate from the detailed nature of the reply by the Minister and as explained in the reply, this is something that is engaging the Minister's special attention. It will be noted that the reply did not in any way include any return criticism of the comments that were made. No doubt the Minister is fully aware of the fact that there is still a certain amount of leeway to be made up and at present he is using his best endeavours to do that.

Is it not a fact that the reply to the question is couched in such a way as to exonerate the Department completely in respect of any deficiencies there are in these services in the Dublin region? Is it not also a fact that the chief psychiatrist does not agree with the view expressed that there are more than enough places for both psychiatric and mentally retarded patients in the Dublin region, and that he had a “go” at the Dublin Health Authority simply because he could not have a “go” at the Minister and for no other reason? There are proposals in the Department——
We cannot have a speech on this matter. Deputy Dr. O'Connell.
The Minister wants to reply to Deputy Clinton.
It is not the Dublin Health Authority that is responsible.

What action is being taken to eliminate the substandard temporary dwelling that has existed for nearly 50 years at Portrane where people are housed in filthy and congested conditions? Will the Minister state what action he has taken on the report to him by the Dublin Health Authority about the elimination of this dreadful place in Portrane?

I am sorry that even with —probably due to—the comprehensive reply, the Deputy obviously gave up listening to it half way through—he did not hear in detail the account of what is being done in this regard. In regard to a number of supplementary questions by Deputy Clinton, the reply is a statement of fact as to the progress which the Minister and the Department have been making and it is certainly not couched in such terms as to be a defence. It is a statement of what progress has been made and of the plans the Minister has for further progress.
I am calling Question No. 10.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Home Accommodation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if, in order to reduce the burden on nursing personnel and disturbance to patients, he will ensure that accommodation, separate from the geriatric units in county homes, is provided to cater for those who at present seek shelter in county homes on a short term basis.

While it is accepted that it would be preferable that casuals of the type referred to in the question should be catered for elsewhere than in county homes, the Deputy will appreciate that in many instances this would not be feasible. Thus in three county homes I have been considering recently, the average number of admissions weekly was three, four and six and cost of the establishment and staffing of separate accommodation for such small numbers would be prohibitive. Where the numbers involved are large, as in Dublin, health authorities have set up such separate accommodation, not staffed by nursing personnel, and where voluntary bodies provide night shelters as portion of their normal activities, the services of such voluntary bodies are availed of by health authorities.
The position is being kept under review.

Would the Minister not agree that in some county homes where there is no separate accommodation the figures are much higher than those he mentioned? Would he also agree that casual people may sometimes come in, possibly in an inebriated condition, at night and may have to be accommodated in wards where there are old people who are trying to sleep and that this disrupts patients and nursing staff who may have to receive them at 4 a.m. if they arrive at that time?

I still think it is something for which the Minister should not have to make special provision in relation to a number of other demands, that is, preparing special facilities for the reception of people coming in in an inebriated condition at all hours of the morning.
Would the Minister not agree that this is really a very important element in geriatric care, that the services may be disrupted by failure to provide in county homes this separate accommodation?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Nursing Service.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is aware of delays in the registration of nurses who have passed all relevant tests; and if he will take steps to eliminate such delays, with particular regard to the registration of public health nurses.
Registration is, of course, a matter for An Bord Altranais.

In so far as general-trained nurses are concerned I understand that hundreds of applications for registration are concentrated in the period immediately following the qualifying examinations which are held twice a year. These applications naturally take some time to process but I am asking the board to review the position and see what could be done to expedite the issue of certificates in those cases.

MainHeading.P: With regard to public health nurses there are at present two main ways of achieving registration. The first way is by means of a special training course and examination. Certificates are issued in those cases the following day after the examination results are announced. The second way is on the basis of experience and service. This is a concession given in 1966 for those nurses who applied for registration as a public health nurse before 1st June, 1970, and who had prior to the 31st May, 1966, a total of five years experience on this work. The processing of these applications has necessarily been time-consuming and some delays were inevitable. The net current position is that all certificates which could be issued have been issued or will issue this week. Correspondence in regard to the remaining cases is proceeding.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will ensure that all service prior to marriage be taken into account in determining the salary paid to married nurses when re-entering the nursing services after marriage.

I feel that the recently introduced arrangement under which, instead of being held at the minimum of the relevant salary scale, married nurses may on appointment be granted up to five increments for previous experience and may be paid annual increments thereafter, reasonably meets the needs of the situation.
Would the Minister not agree that once five increments have been granted it is only logical to go the whole way and that there is no further point of principle involved?
The steps already taken should be given some chance.

Would the Minister not agree that this marginal concession to nursing staffs was a disgraceful decision on the part of the Government? Does he accept it is a non-recognition of the pre-marriage nursing service of nurses? The principle at issue is that a nurse who marries must go back to the first point on the incremental scale, and may I ask——
This is a speech not a question.
This is discrimination against women who marry.

I said in reply that married nurses may on appointment be granted up to five increments for previous experience and may be paid annual increments thereafter. This is the progress that has been made so far, and following on the review of the effects of the present concession by the employers, the extension of the concession could be considered on its merits.
It should not be a question of a concession on the part of the employers.
The Deputy must put a question.

Would the Minister agree in principle that it is discriminatory and grossly unfair that women's pre-marriage nursing service should not be recognised in the normal way without being regarded as a concession to women nurses who happen to marry?
I prefer not to comment.
Why?
It is not my Department. I am replying on behalf of the Tánaiste.
Talk about discrimination in the north. If you get married here you lose your service.
asked the Minister for Health if he will outline progress to date in eliminating the necessity for nurses to carry out non-nursing duties.

Following my reception last month of a deputation from the Irish Nurses' Organisation, and a subsequent exchange of views between my officers and the managers of local health authorities, I arranged for the issue, earlier this month, of a circular letter urging that each health authority, in consultation with the nursing staffs, should examine the extent to which the performance of non-nursing duties by general-trained nurses can be eliminated or reduced in scope or diverted to non-nursing staff without detriment to the safety, care or comfort of the patients.

Simultaneously, I urged that each health authority should consider the establishment of staff relations committees in its hospitals as a useful means of communication between management and nursing staff at local level.
At my request, the Hospitals Commission are considering a similar approach to the boards of voluntary hospitals.

MainHeading.P: I am confident that the reaction from the managements of health authorities and voluntary hospitals will be favourable and that concrete results will be achieved.

Speaker.P: What proposals has the Minister to follow up this circular to ensure action is taken on it as soon as possible?
The Deputy has asked to know if the Minister would outline the progress to date, and this is the statement of the progress to date. He did not ask a question about plans for the future.

Is the Minister aware that following the concession of the 80-hour fortnight to nursing personnel, the managers' association gave instructions that a number of nursing jobs being done by nurses should be done by non-nursing personnel, and that no extra staff was to be recruited for the purpose of filling in the time which would be lost because of the reduction in working hours? Would the Minister care to comment on that?
It is a separate issue.
It is not. There is no point in the Minister or his Department making a statement to the effect that——
We cannot have a long discussion on this.
It is not a discussion.
It is a long speech by the Deputy.

That comment from you was unfair. I simply asked a question of the Minister and when I was about to ask for further information you intervened. My question is: is the Minister for Health or his Department aware that instructions have been given that no extra nurses are to be employed in local authority hospitals to make up for the slack which will occur as a result of the reduction in the working fortnight to 80 hours? If the Minister has not got that information, perhaps he would pass the question on to his colleague, the Minister for Health?
I shall convey the Deputy's view to the Minister.
I represent non-nursing personnel in hospitals and I am not going to see them kicked around between the nurses' association and the county managers.

asked the Minister for Health if he will authorise the extension of loan facilities to newly appointed public health nurses to assist them in the purchase of motors cars which are essential for their work.
Neither I, as Minister for Health, nor health authorities have power to provide or authorise loan facilities for the purpose referred to by the Deputy.

Would the Minister not consider the provision of such facilities in view of the fact that the cost of acquiring a car by hire-purchase has increased substantially and that a car is necessary for the efficient carrying out of a public health nurse's work?
The Minister has not the power.
Would he not acquire the power?
It would be inappropriate to single out an individual category of local authority staff for special treatment of this nature.
Would the Minister not agree a public health nurse's work is such that it is essential to have a car?
Question No. 15.

asked the Minister for Health if he will state if public health nurses are receiving the full mileage allowance in respect of all miles travelled by them in the course of their work in all counties; and, if not, why.
Payment of travelling allowances, or recoupment of travelling expenses incurred, is primarily a matter for the health authority concerned.

MainHeading.P: Since 1966 public health nurses serving in mainly rural districts are paid mileage rates in respect of their travelling. Travelling allowances within a maximum of £100 a year—shortly to be revised—are paid to public health nurses on district nursing duties in mainly urban districts. If a good case can be made in any particular instance for a change from this method of recoupment to mileage rates, I am sure it will be considered sympathetically by the health authority.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if it is proposed to increase the number of nursing officers in his Department to cater for all branches of the nursing profession.

While it is proposed to increase the number of nursing officers in the Department, it is not accepted that it should be necesary that separate appointments should be made in respect of every branch of the nursing profession.
What increases will take place?
That has not finally been decided.
How many officers are there at the moment?
One.
How many for the medical profession?
I have not got that information. That was not asked.
asked the Minister for Health if all nurses who have passed all relevant tests and have applied for registration are paid the full nurses' salary or merely the student nurses' salary.

I understand that until recent years student nurses in most of the training hospitals were on a four-year contract of service and that they were paid at student rates for the fourth year even though they normally qualified and became eligible for registration at the end of three years.

In 1966 the Irish Nurses' Organisation proposed that the fourth year obligation should be abandoned. This was agreed to and meant, of course, that a student who had successfully completed her examinations and had been registered by An Bord Altranais would be placed on the salary scale for a staff nurse.

MainHeading.P: I am not aware of any instance in which this arrangement has not been implemented.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - River Dodder Pollution.

I have seen the Press report referred to regarding pollution in the Dodder River.
The matter is primarily one for the Dublin Corporation who, I understand, are investigating the position with a view to preventing a recurrence.
The chief medical officer, Dublin, is not aware of any cases of skin rash arising out of bathing in the river.

Is the Minister aware that there have been several reports that bird life and fish life have been deleteriously affected by the pollution in question? Is he aware that the local authority and the health authority, not-withstanding this evidence and the complaints of harm to human beings, have failed to take any action in the matter?

I am aware that there have been a few complaints. The report from the CEO in Dublin is that there have been no cases of skin rash arising from bathing in this river and that the matter is primarily one for the Dublin Corporation.
I know to the contrary, on medical advice.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Appointment of Ombudsman.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for External Affairs what action was taken by the Government on the invitation of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe to consider the possibility of setting up an institution such as the Scandinavian Ombudsman for the speedy and inexpensive investigation of individual complaints of alleged violation of rights by the administration; and in particular what was the nature and extent of the investigation which was conducted before the Committee of Ministers was informed that existing institutions in Ireland were satisfactory; by whom such information was given to the Committee; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: On 27th January, 1970 the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe sent a reply to the Consultative Assembly in regard to the Recommendation No. 548 relating to this subject in which it was stated that a number of countries including Ireland considered existing institutions satisfactory and that no need was felt to set up the additional machinery of the ombudsman.
The Government's position in this matter was stated in some detail on behalf of the Taoiseach in reply to a question in the House on 15th May, 1968.

Accepting that the Government are not prepared to acknowledge the need for an ombudsman, does the Minister not agree that there is a body of opinion that the system of an ombudsman would be justified, and does the Minister think it correct that a body like the Council of Europe, which represents all the parliamentarians in Europe, should be informed that there is no feeling in Ireland for the need for an ombudsman?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach said, on 23rd October last year when speaking on the debate on the situation in the Six Counties, that he would not be averse from examining the possibility of this matter, but it is pertinent to say that we here have a very democratic system in which there is a total availability of local and national representatives where the people are concerned and the rights are remedied——
Not in Dublin or Bray.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: ——through questions here in the House and in my view there is no strong demand for this sort of institution that has arisen and is working in countries that have not got our strong democratic type of system in which representatives are readily available to the public.
The truth is that the Council of Europe were misinformed when they were told that there was no demand here for this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: I prefer to regard ourselves as fulfilling this role.
Is the Minister aware that the Reverend Paisley also claims that he is totally available to his constituents and does this mean that everything in the garden is rosy just because he is available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: We do not have the same type of society down here in which there are Reverend Ian Paisleys.

Is the Minister aware that the Taoiseach when advocating the abolition of PR stated that one of the reasons he advocated it was that a number of Deputies all over the country were pretending to do things for the public which they were not doing at all?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: That is a different matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy refers to the application lodged on 10th April, 1970 and considered by the European Commission of Human Rights at its session which ended on 29th May, 1970.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my reply to questions on this subject in the Dáil on 7th July, 1970, when I indicated that on that day I had received assurances from the Ambassador of Nigeria about the distribution of food supplies in adequate amounts in the area in question.

That is unfortunate. In view of the fact that the session is coming to an end would the Minister agree to take a question on this next week, if the Ceann Comhairle would agree to that procedure? We want to be informed about this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: I will mention that to the Minister for External Affairs who will, I am sure, communicate with the Deputy. This is a very serious and complex problem and there are limits to what we can do.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Armed Conflicts.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for External Affairs if he will outline the initiatives taken by Ireland in the past ten years at the UN and elsewhere to update and to strengthen international conventions dealing with methods and weapons used in declared and undeclared international and civil wars; and if he will indicate his future policy in this regard.

asked the Minister for External Affairs if he will outline the initiatives taken by Ireland in the past ten years at the UN and elsewhere to update and strengthen the Geneva Convention on Human Rights in armed conflicts; and if he will indicate his future policy in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose taking Questions Nos. 25 and 26 together.

MainHeading.P: I assume that the Deputy is referring to the principal international instruments dealing with the law of war namely, the Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907, the Geneva Protocol of 1925 on the Prohibition of the Use in War of Asphyxiating, Poisonous or other Gases and of Bacteriological Methods of Warfare, and the four Geneva Conventions of 1949.

On the instructions of the Government the Irish Delegation at the United Nations cosponsored resolution 2603A adopted on 16th December, 1969 at the 24th Session of the General Assembly which declared any chemical and biological agents of warfare as contrary to the recognised rules of international law as embodied in the Geneva Protocol of 1925. I might add that the Government have supported at the United Nations General Assembly, at the International Conference on Human Rights at Teheran in 1968 and at the International Red Cross Conference in Istanbul in 1969 the relevant resolutions on Human Rights in Armed Conflicts.

In regard to future policy I can assure the Deputy that the Government will pursue their efforts in the United Nations and elsewhere to promote effective international measures for updating and strengthening the international conventions on the law of war.

Apart from the law of war I might add Ireland has taken an active part in promoting effective disarmament measures. The most important Irish initiative in this field dealt with the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons.

Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that one of the big difficulties is the fact that they do not sufficiently cover situations of undeclared war like the war in Vietnam, South East Asia and Nigeria and this is one of the fields which need the greatest study?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: That is true. I agree with the Deputy.
Would the Minister say if the CS gas purchased in large quantities by the Irish Government comes into the categories he has mentioned?
That does not arise on this question.
Would the Minister agree that some of the resolutions are only resolutions and have not reached the status of international conventions and further initiative will be required from the Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Lenihan Mr. B. Lenihan
Speaker.P: That is what I said. Efforts must be pursued in this direction to make the resolutions effective in the real sense of the word.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Organisation and Methods.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the number of staff currently engaged in Organisation and Methods work in his Department; the type of work carried out by them to date; and his future plans in this field.
There are at present seven officers in my Department who are working full time in the field of organisation and methods (O and M). The work has also the part-time attention of supervising officers.

Because much of the work of the O and M officers in my Department is carried out for other Departments, frequently on a team basis with O and M staff in these Departments, I think I should explain that, in the Civil Service as a whole, there are 45 officers engaged full time on O and M and two occupied part time, aside from supervisory staff.

The type of work done up to the present in the field of O and M has been the investigation of systems and procedures and the examination of organisation structures in various sections of the Civil Service, both indoor and outdoor, and the presentation of recommendations and advice to management designed to increase efficiency. In the examination of procedures, O and M keeps abreast of the constant progress in the field of office machinery, conducts tests on newly-developed machines and promotes the use in the Civil Service of suitable modern office machinery of proven performance. The development of automatic data processing and computers in the Civil Service, which now constitutes a specialised field in itself, originated from activities of an O and M character.
Within the new Public Service Department I intend to lay increasing stress on the development and extension of O and M and kindred activities designed to raise levels of efficiency.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Turnover Tax.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if all Government Departments are registered for turnover tax; and, if not, why.

Government Departments are not registered for turnover tax because receipts from services provided by the State are exempt from the tax. The fact that Government Departments are not registered for turnover tax does not mean that they escape the impact of the tax. Suppliers of taxable goods or services to the Departments are liable for tax on their receipts, and they include their liability in the prices charged to Departments. Goods imported by Departments are liable to tax.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance when work will commence on the dredging of Dingle harbour as the delay in carrying out the work is seriously hampering the development of the fishing industry in Dingle.

The grant of £108,000 sanctioned by Roinn na Gaeltachta for dredging and other improvements at Dingle harbour was subject to the condition that Kerry County Council and Dingle Harbour Commisioners would contribute to the cost of future maintenance dredging. MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Private Nursery Schools.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education what controls are in existence on privately run nursery schools; and if they are inspected.
Privately-run nursery schools are not controlled and are not inspected by my Department.

Would the Minister not agree that it is highly desirable that nursery schools set up by people who cater for and take into their care children of very tender years should be inspected frequently by officers of the Department?

I do not agree with the Deputy in so far as I doubt if it would be the function of the Department to look after children of that particular age. We have the lowest minimum age for admission to primary schools in Europe — four years.

Considerable difficulty is experienced by parents in getting their children into primary school. A number of them avail of the opportunity of sending children of three, four and five years to these nursery schools. It helps to alleviate the overcrowding, particularly in the Dublin area, of these schools. Surely there is a responsibility on the Minister's Department to ensure that these schools are properly run not only by qualified people but by people who will not undermine the character of children of that age?

I doubt very much if the reasons given by the Deputy are the reasons why children are being sent to these nursery schools. Apart from nursery schools, there are nurseries and play groups. It does not seem very clear in most people's minds which is which. Generally speaking, because we have a very low admission age, I think it is not and would not be likely to be a matter for the Department of Education.
Is there not control of these schools in Britain? We seem very fond of imitating the British. To the best of my knowledge, there is control of these schools there.
I do not know.
As we are so fond of imitating the British, let the Minister imitate them here too.
Would I be correct in assuming from the Minister's reply that, while he might agree with the necessity for this supervision, he does not agree that his is the appropriate Department?
In some instances, perhaps there may be need for supervision, but not necessarily in relation to nursery schools. There might be in relation to some of the other categories.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Mussel Industry.

Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries (Mr. Fahey)
Speaker.P: For a number of years past my Department and An Bord Iascaigh Mhara in association with the local fishermen's co-operative society have been actively engaged in the transplantation of seed mussels in Castlemaine Harbour to areas in the harbour where fattening conditions are more favourable and it is intended that this work will be continued. MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Fishing Industry.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries if and when it is intended to develop the vast potential for employment that is available by developing our fishing industry on European lines and so get a part of the vast market that is available for fish products in the Common Market countries.

The development of our fishing industry is already proceeding along the lines indicated in the Government White Paper entitled Programme of Sea Fisheries Development, published in April, 1962, and in the Third Programme for Economic and Social Development, published in March, 1969, and the results so far achieved are very satisfactory. Since 1962, the value of our fish landings has increased by 100 per cent, and the value of exports by about 120 per cent. In 1969, the actual value of landings of fish — excluding salmon — at almost £3 million and of all fishery exports at £3.5 million were all-time records. The market outlets abroad for our fish are increasing and, while Britain continues to be our largest customer, considerable exports are made to the EEC, particularly to France, Germany and the Netherlands. In fact, the exports to the EEC are achieved in the face of various import restrictions.
